awd_titl_txt: Travel: NSF Student Travel for 2023 USENIX Conferences SOUPS 2023 and Security 2023
awd_abstract_narration:
The USENIX Security Conference is one of the most important research conferences for professionals to present cutting edge research of fundamental importance to advancing understanding of computer systems security. Published research has specific application to security threats and vulnerabilities in computing systems; the design, implementation and implications of systems software; virtualization, system and network management and troubleshooting; cloud and edge computing; security, privacy, and trust; mobile and wireless systems; and more. This award provides funding for approximately 25 students to attend the 18th USENIX Symposium on Usable Privacy and Security (SOUPS ‘23) and the 32nd USENIX Security Symposium (Security ‘23).

USENIX conferences gather researchers from across the academic, government, and industry communities to foster cross-disciplinary approaches and to address shared research challenges. This cross-disciplinary emphasis makes them well-suited as a target for student participation, and the important topics addressed in these conferences encourage student research and collaboration in critical areas of advanced computing. This award enables the participation of students who would otherwise be unable to attend the conferences. It also extends the impact of research presented to a broader audience inclusive of junior researchers from across the country. For 2023, USENIX events are planned to be in-person events, with virtual participation if pandemic conditions require.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering
org_div_long_name: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

por.por_cntn:
This NSF-funded grant provided travel funding to assist US-based graduate students to attend two USENIX events in 2023, specifically the Nineteenth Symposium on Usable Privacy and Security (SOUPS 2023) and the 32nd USENIX Security Symposium (USENIX Security ‘23).

SOUPS 2023 took place August 6-8, 2023 in Anaheim, California, and focused on human-computer interaction, security, and privacy. USENIX Security ‘23, which took place August 9-11, 2023 in the same location, was a forum for the latest advances in the security and privacy of computer systems and networks.

Participation in these and similar conferences is a valuable and important part of the graduate school experience. It provides students with the opportunity to interact with more senior researchers in the field, and exposes students to leading-edge work in the field. This grant made possible the participation of students, primarily Ph.D. candidates, who would otherwise be unable to attend the conferences and extended the impact of research presented to a broad audience of young researchers from across the country. Participating students at each event were offered activities to enhance their interactions with senior researchers and organizers, including speed mentoring events, a student meetup, poster sessions, and receptions. The NSF funding provided under this award allowed us to substantially increase the number of students we could support with grants for SOUPS 2023 and USENIX Security ‘23. 

Any student enrolled full-time at an accredited US university or college was eligible to apply for a grant. Grants had two components: 1) registration costs and 2) expenses. For those students selected, USENIX covered registration costs by providing students with a registration code for full student registration. For the expense portion, USENIX provided payment to assist the student with costs related to airfare and lodging. Variations in the rates offered depended on how far a student needed to travel and the amount they requested (i.e., some students may stay with a friend in the town of the conference and therefore not have a hotel expense). We confirmed that the student recipients registered and attended the event. 

The criteria we used in selecting grant recipients included:

  • Conference participation (e.g., presenting a poster)

  • Areas of study that significantly overlapped with the conference topics

  • The pertinence of supporting statement outlining the applicant’s research

  • Application history, prioritizing first-time applicants and those not receiving a grant in the previous twelve months

  • Students from institutions not traditionally represented at USENIX events

  • Students from historically underrepresented communities and minorities

  • Class level, prioritizing graduate students, and financial need

NSF funding supported a total of 37 grants for students to participate in the two events. 

  • For SOUPS 2023, USENIX received 45 grant applications from students and awarded 15 grants. The NSF funds of $13,950 covered 13 of these grants, and all those awardees were enrolled at U.S. universities. There were 278 attendees at SOUPS 2023, which included 101 student attendees.

  • For USENIX Security ‘23, we received 184 grant applications from students and awarded 46 grants. The NSF funds of $26,050 covered 24 of these grants, and all those awardees were enrolled at U.S. universities. There were 1,106 attendees at Security ‘23, which included 406 student attendees in total.

 

 


Last Modified: 01/04/2024
Modified by: Catherine   Bergman

This NSF-funded grant provided travel funding to assist US-based graduate students to attend two USENIX events in 2023, specifically the Nineteenth Symposium on Usable Privacy and Security (SOUPS 2023) and the 32nd USENIX Security Symposium (USENIX Security 23).


SOUPS 2023 took place August 6-8, 2023 in Anaheim, California, and focused on human-computer interaction, security, and privacy. USENIX Security 23, which took place August 9-11, 2023 in the same location, was a forum for the latest advances in the security and privacy of computer systems and networks.

We confirmed that the student recipients registered and attended the event.

Conference participation (e.g., presenting a poster)




Areas of study that significantly overlapped with the conference topics

Students from institutions not traditionally represented at USENIX events




Students from historically underrepresented communities and minorities




Class level, prioritizing graduate students, and financial need

For SOUPS 2023, USENIX received 45 grant applications from students and awarded 15 grants. The NSF funds of $13,950 covered 13 of these grants, and all those awardees were enrolled at U.S. universities. There were 278 attendees at SOUPS 2023, which included 101 student attendees.

There were 1,106 attendees at Security 23, which included 406 student attendees in total.
